caption: Sunset illuminates a woman walking toward the Plaza de los Trabajadores, Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016
Men play chess under a portrait of revolutionary Che Guevara in Camagüey. Cubans have long placed among some of the world's best players. Saturday June 25, 2016.
A family holds their littlest up to get a better view of a live band playing during San Juan Camagueyano, an annual summer festival in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Dance and musical performances end the night for the San Juan Camagüeyano festival celebrated in late June every year. Saturday June 25, 2016.
A taxi driver behind the wheel of a classic Pontiac Silver Streak in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Walkers in Camagüey province use an umbrella to shield themselves from the intense summer sun. Sunday June 26, 2016.

La Iglesia San Juan de Dios glows in the evening light in Camagüey. The church adjoins a museum, formerly a hospital. The plaza below has great historical significance as the place where Cuban war hero Ignacio Agramonte's body was brought after he was killed fighting for independence from Spain in 1873. Saturday June 25, 2016.
The streets in Camagüey wind in maze-like patterns with bright colors and narrow alleys. Saturday June 25, 2016.
Anthony Alejandro, 3, peers out of his doorway in Camagüey, where people seem to live their lives on the sidewalk with doors open, visiting and hanging out with each other. Saturday June 25, 2016.
A carnaval drummer walks down República street to participate in the annual San Juan Camagüeyano summer festival in Camagüey, Cuba Sunday June 26, 2016.
A fruit and vegetable vendor rolls door-to-door around the winding streets of Camagüey Saturday June 25, 2016.
Locals hang out on the sidewalk playing dominoes and drinking beer in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Ajiaco, a Cuban stew, is boiled in giant pots set over flames just off the sidewalk in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
The Necrópolis de Camagüey looks like a sea of bleached-white tombs with scattered ruins under the hot sun. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Mourners arrive for a funeral at the Necrópolis de Camagüey. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Graffiti celebrates Fidel Castro, the 90-year-old revolutionary leader, in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Juan Díaz Salazar is the first to board a train from Camagüey to the Cuban city of Florida. Monday June 27, 2016.
The streets of Camagüey, Cuba are brilliant colors, set off by a red umbrella to keep the sun away. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Families often fit as many extra riders as they can on bicycles in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Police and army officers take a break at their outpost in the center of town in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.

Ramón Álvarez Caballero fixes wristwatches at the train station in Camagüey, Cuba. He has been fixing watches for 26 years, previously employed by the state, and now working on his own.  Monday June 27, 2016.
The accountant at the train station sifts through a mountain of paperwork in her office in Camagüey, Cuba Monday June 27, 2016.
People stroll down busy República street in Camagüey, Cuba.  Monday June 27, 2016.
U.S. influence is strong in Cuba, seen on this cyclist wearing Nikes, and pants emblazoned with the American flag and dollar in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.

Workers make renovations to a colonial plaza in Camagüey, Cuba, with a giant tinajón, a clay pot for water, that is symbolic of the city in the center. Beautification projects across the city have made vast improvements, and the city was recently designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Monday June 27, 2016.
Nicolás Baisinde, a vendor at an outdoor market selling onions, garlic and squash, looks out from under his straw hat in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
Neighborhood conversations happen through a window in Camagüey, Cuba.  Monday June 27, 2016.
Men deliver a cartful of green bananas to a stall in the outdoor market in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
Seattle Times reporter Ángel González finds a distant relative after striking up a conversation with a bus station attendant in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
Rutnelvis Rustan braids her 8-year-old daughter Dailiana Mora's hair while waiting at the bus station in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
A bicitaxi, similar to a pedicab, races down the street in Camagüey. Saturday June 25, 2016.
The scene outside and inside the Fábrica de Arte Cubano in Vedado, Havana, is lively, especially as night falls. Friday June 24, 2016.
Participants in a free tango lesson practice with partners at the Fábrica de Arte Cubano in Vedado, Havana.  Friday June 24, 2016.

People hang out on the patio at the Fábrica de Arte Cubano, bathed in blue and purple light, in Vedado, Havana. The Fábrica -- literally, Factory of Art -- is a museum of contemporary art, event and performance space, nightclub, and all-around popular place for tourists and the young Cuban middle class. Friday June 24, 2016.

People wait to enter the Fábrica de Arte Cubano, in Vedado, Havana. Cost of admission is 2 Cuban convertible pesos (the equivalent of $2 in the tourist currency) or 50 Cuban pesos. Entrants are given a card to record all of their food and drink to pay at the end. Friday June 24, 2016.
Seattle Times reporter Ángel González gets a hug from Livita Castillo, a distant cousin still living in Camagüey. His visit was a surprise; he was last there 15 years ago. Saturday June 25, 2016.

Ángel González catches up with his family in Camagüey. They all descend from the same great-grandfather, Col. Ángel Castillo y Quesada, whose picture is on the wall to the left. He was the son of Ángel del Castillo Agramonte, the general who fell in battle fighting for independence from Spain, who has a monument in Lázaro López. Saturday June 25, 2016.

A portrait of Col. Ángel Castillo y Quesada hangs on the wall of the Castillo family home in Camagüey. He was the son of Ángel del Castillo Agramonte, the general who fell in battle fighting for independence from Spain, who has a monument in Lázaro López. Saturday June 25, 2016.

Haroldo Castillo, 9, still plays with the dress sword of his great-great grandfather at home in Camagüey, Cuba. In many ways, their family is still living in the history that other relatives, forced out in exile, had to leave behind. Saturday June 25, 2016.
Livia Castillo holds a portrait of Ángel's great grandmother, Antonia Vidal, at their home in Camagüey, Cuba. Saturday June 25, 2016.
Livia Castillo brings out family photos to share at her home in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Livia Castillo guides her husband, Haroldo Sr., back to his sitting chair after lunch at their home in Camagüey, Cuba. Sunday June 26, 2016.

Livita Castillo, center, leads her family, from left, Livia, Victor Manuel, Haroldo Sr. and Haroldo Jr., in prayer for their relative Ángel González, right, before the reporter leaves Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
Cubans hang out along the Malecón in Havana after midnight, playing music, drinking and chatting. Tuesday June 21, 2016.
Almendrónes, vintage car taxis that travel a specific route and pick up passengers along the way, are a common sight along Avenida 23 in the Vedado neighborhood of Havana. Wednesday June 22, 2016.
Coworkers from a hotel share the backseat of an almendrón taxi on their way home from work in Havana, Cuba. Thursday June 23, 2016.
Splashes of red are aglow in La Rampa in the Vedado neighborhood in Havana, Cuba. Wednesday June 22, 2016.

American influence, although stifled by the Revolution, is clearly visible in Havana with the classic 1950s cars and the design of El Capitolio. The building was completed in 1929 and was emptied of lawmakers during the revolution 30 years later. Today it is under massive renovations to be restored to its original use as the seat of government. Thursday June 23, 2016.
Liseet Castillo, 39, mops the floor of a bakery in Centro Habana next to a poster of Hugo ChC!vez, former Venezuelan ruler, and a main ally of Cuba and Fidel Castro.  Friday June 24, 2016.
Workers deep clean a giant statue of activist, writer and national hero José Martí in Parque Central in the Habana Vieja neighborhood. Thursday June 23, 2016.
Buses in Havana, Cuba seem to always be crowded.  Wednesday June 29, 2016.
Boys play on one of many streets full of construction in Habana Vieja, Havana. Wednesday June 29, 2016.

Reenactors dressed in their 18th century military regalia walk by the tourist booths for their 9 p.m. cañonazo ceremony, where they do a formal procession and fire a cannon, at the Fortaleza de San Carlos de la Cabaña in Havana. Monday June 28, 2016.
Tourists take pictures along the Malecón in a classic convertible car in Havana, Cuba. Thursday June 30, 2016.
The view of Havana from the Fortaleza de San Carlos de la Cabaña, with El Capitolio in the center, in Cuba. Monday June 28, 2016.
Workers push heavy construction materials down the street in Centro Habana towards the Vedado neighborhood. Friday June 24, 2016.

Amparito Fajardo, 75, holds a photograph of one of the many family members she misses who live in the United States. She said she tried living there for a while, but missed the vibrancy of life in Havana. Wednesday June 29, 2016.
High ceilings and bright colors are the norm throughout palatial buildings in Centro Habana. Wednesday June 22, 2016.
Women try and entice men into a club while walking through Centro Habana late at night Wednesday June 22, 2016.
Destroyed books sit in an abandoned military depot in the Vedado neighborhood of Havana. June 24, 2016.
Ahmed Argilago used to be an agronomist, but now works as a security guard at the Escuela Nacional Cubana de Ballet. Thursday June 23, 2016.
Stray dogs and cats wander torn-up streets in Centro Habana. Wednesday June 22, 2016.
Men deliver goods to market by bike in Havana -- a common sight due to the high price of cars. Thursday June 30, 2016.

This old aristocratic house in the Vedado neighborhood of Havana, formerly owned by the Loynaz Del Castillo family, used to house some of Cuba’s most prestigious personalities and artists, but is now inhabited by almost 40 people. Thursday June 23, 2016.
Israel Rojas Alphonso packages roses with glitter and sells them on the street in Vedado, Havana. Thursday June 30, 2016.
Taxis cruise down the Malecón on a steamy late afternoon in Havana. Thursday June 23, 2016.
The view out of an almendrón driving in Vedado, Havana, Cuba. Thursday June 30, 2016.
Construction projects, stalled and in-progress, abound around Havana, with poured concrete and large cranes. June 24, 2016.
Building material salvage workers take a break in Havana, Cuba. Wednesday June 29, 2016.
A girl talks to a neighbor through a gate in Havana, Cuba. Wednesday June 29, 2016.
Boys play soccer along the Paseo del Prado, Havana, which divides Centro Habana and Habana Vieja Wednesday June 22, 2016.
The view of Centro Habana from La Guarida's new rooftop bar in Cuba. La Guarida is the paladar, or privately owned restaurant, where the 1993 film 'Fresa y Chocolate' was filmed. Wednesday June 29
Classic cars and bicitaxis, similar to pedicabs, sputter through the streets of Centro Habana in the early morning hours. Wednesday June 22, 2016.
Manager Hosmay González, 33, left, and Pedro Basulto, 37, a store clerk, sell eggs to a woman according to her ration card at a corner market in Centro Habana Friday June 24, 2016.

Seattle Times reporter Ángel González visits a memorial for his ancestor Ángel del Castillo Agramonte in Lázaro López, Ciego de Ávila province, Cuba. He was a wealthy planter in the late 1800s who rose up against Spain for Cuban independence, and was known for his recklessness. 'They called him la tempestad a caballo, which is like a storm on horseback,' González said. Saturday June 25, 2016.

Gregory Biniowsky is a Canadian lawyer who also runs Nazdarovie, a retro-Soviet restaurant on the Malecón in Havana. Biniowsky has lived in Cuba for more than 20 years and specializes in consulting with international companies who want to invest or do business in Cuba and Latin America. June 24, 2016.
Ángel González takes a picture of Havana from the Fortaleza de San Carlos de la Cabaña in Cuba. Monday June 28, 2016.
The Christ of Havana statue overlooks the flare stack of the Nico López oil refinery in Cuba.  Monday June 28, 2016.
Reporter Ángel González looks out at Havana from the Fortaleza de San Carlos de la Cabaña in Cuba Monday June 28, 2016.

Efraín Izquierdo, 90, stands in Restaurante 1800, his family's gleaming and successful paladar, or privately-owned restaurant, in Camagüey, Cuba. The Izquierdos sold property and got a loan to transform the building into a restaurant, and after opening in 2012, are planning to expand. Monday June 27, 2016.
In the heat of the afternoon, Cubans build a house in the countryside in Ciego de Ávila province. Saturday June 25, 2016.
A vintage car in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.

Peña, our hired taxi driver, took us to Camagüey from Havana. He said his Kia, with a couple years and 300,000 miles on it, is worth the equivalent of more than $40,000 in Cuba because of the short supply and high demand for cars. Before driving a taxi, he was in the Army's special forces Saturday. June 25, 2016.
Horse-drawn carriages are still a very popular form of public transit in Camagüey, Cuba. Monday June 27, 2016.
Wires abound as a mechanic rebuilds a car on the streets of Havana. Wednesday June 29, 2016.
Older cars still reign in Havana, but newer models are creeping in. Wednesday June 29, 2016.
A very old car drives by an abandoned military depot in Vedado, Havana, painted with sunset light. Friday June 24, 2016.
Tourists take pictures along Havana's Malecón in a convertible taxi. Thursday June 30, 2016.

Ernestino Medina, the chef at La Paladar Maria in Taguasco, Sancti Spíritus, Cuba takes care of his kitchen, cooking over open flames. Paladars are privately-owned restaurants, as opposed to state-owned -- they are generally higher quality.   Saturday June 25, 2016.

Ernestino Medina, the chef at La Paladar Maria in Taguasco, Sancti Spíritus, Cuba makes tamales, adding water as it boils off over open flames. Paladars are privately-owned restaurants, as opposed to state-owned -- they are generally higher quality, and in cities, more expensive.   Saturday June 25, 2016.

Fernando started his professional career as a doctor, but then chose to drive a taxi to make better money. Doctors reportedly now make up to the equivalent of $67 per month, whereas taxi drivers for foreign tourists can make over $600 per month. Tuesday June 21, 2016.
Kids take turns riding in toy cars at a parque infantil
José Antonio Velásquez Gómez, 72, started a portrait and photo reprint studio in a free-enterprise shopping mall that recently popped up in Havana. Thursday June 30, 2016.

The Santa Isabel Sugar Mill in Camagüey province, Cuba, used to be owned by Ángel del Castillo, reporter Ángel González's great-great grandfather. It didn't operate for long, as Ángel del Castillo joined the Cuban rebels, and the Spanish bombed it to ruin. Now it is a historical site with a snack bar. Sunday June 26, 2016.

Formerly high-tech gears can still be found at the Santa Isabel Sugar Mill in Camagüey province, Cuba, a mill that was owned by Ángel del Castillo, reporter Ángel González's great-great grandfather. He went to school in the United States and brought back modern machinery so the mill could end its use of slaves. Sunday June 26, 2016.
Israel Salazar, 68, has lived behind the Santa Isabel Sugar Mill in Camagüey province, Cuba, since 2008 Sunday June 26, 2016.
Clandestina, a local clothing and design boutique opened by Idania del RC-o and Leire FernC!ndez, is thriving in Habana Vieja, Cuba. Thursday June 30, 2016.
Idania del RC-o, a designer behind the popular Clandestina design boutique in Habana Vieja, Cuba. Thursday June 30, 2016.
